title: How are you doing?
description: A journey through the complexity of emotions.
byline: By Abby VanMuijen with Michelle McGhee

text: Hi there, and welcome! We are about to go on a journey that explores emotions.
If that sounds like something you’re up for, scroll or key your character forward. If not, that’s okay too– feel free to come back any other time.
If at any point, you want to take a break, you can click the pause button in the top right.
Hi, how are you doing?
Hi there, my name is Abby. I have been exploring the topic of “feelings” lately. Can I show you what I’ve been learning?
Until recently, I would always answer the question “how are you doing?” with one of those options– “okay,” “good,” “not so good,” or my favorite…“busy.”
But then that started to change.
I started to experience panic attacks, self harm, depression, and anxiety.
So I got my butt into therapy (where they don't let you off the hook with answers like this...).
My therapist suggested I use a feelings wheel to help improve my "emotional vocabulary."
I could choose words from the wheel to be more specific about how I was feeling and give that feeling a name.
You can choose up to 3.
Who knew– you can feel more than one feeling at once!

This kind of specificity of emotional vocabulary is what Dr. Lisa Feldman Barrett has coined "emotional granularity." When we can get specific about the emotions we're feeling, we can more easily identify what our body is telling us it needs. Pretty cool, eh?
I also thought it was interesting that the wheel was organized by color and category. Although I didn't quite like the colors and categories on the wheels I found...
Colors can have very strong emotional associations - but they're different for everyone.
I started to do this every day - I'd write the words I was feeling and the color I associated with that feeling.
I found a lot of my associations lined up with the colors & character designs from the Pixar movie "Inside Out" - so I studied their process.
It turns out, most scientists agree, there are at least 5 core emotions that track back to the way our bodies intuitively communicate our needs to our caregivers before we have language.
Isn’t that FASCINATING?
So I added a new element to my practice - tracking how feelings showed up in my body and facial expressions.
When I feel frustrated, it looks like this:

Take a moment here to pause and notice your body. Start at the top-most part of your body and scan down through your center, out to your edges. Make a mark on the diagram on the right based on what you notice.
I started to notice some patterns in how the colors I was using lined up with how and where the feelings showed up in my body.
From there I could track that to some patterns of what my body was trying to ask for.
Did that last picture feel a little overwhelming?
Our bodies are the source of SO much information and it can be really hard to know where to begin. I’ve found it helpful to start with this question: “What is my body asking for in this moment?”
Do any of the options to the right seem like something your body might be asking for?
You can click up to 5.
Dr. Brené Brown says there are as many theories on emotions as there are emotions researchers - which seems right to me.
And while I'm more of an artist than a researcher, this work has helped me very deeply.
I ended up turning all of this into my own emotion wheel.

I’m still learning, but it has been nice to use the words, the colors, the body diagram and the needs chart to better understand and express how I'm doing each day and what I may be needing to experience more joy (satisfied needs) in my life.
I no longer answer the question “how are you doing?” the same way.
And I hold other people’s answers with more tenderness.
In difficult moments, I have some more tools to pause… and ask myself “what word is this? What color is it? Where do I notice it? What is my body telling me it needs?”
I try to do this in my sketchbook every day. These are some of my drawings.

A nice punchy conclusion bit that’s about how feelings aren’t good/bad, they’re data– and also why covering up the places where we’re hurting only leads to more hurt for us and for others. *So, everyone get better at feelings plz
I’m so glad you came on this journey with me. I hope it was helpful for you.
As a souvenir, my friend Michelle and I made you this picture (to the right). You can save it or go back and change parts or keep walking to see some more art that I made.
There is more art ahead!

As a heads up, some of the drawings get into more emotionally complicated topics than the art you’ve seen so far. If you hover over each cloud, you can see the topic it’s about and choose if you’d like to click in to explore more deeply.
Thanks for making it all the way to the end! You’re welcome to come back to this page or the activities page any time you’d like.
If you’re interested in digging deeper, here are some of the resources that inspired and informed this work.

comments.text: For this activity, I write out all the things going on in my life and then go through and watercolor the colors that feel associated with how that thing feels (mine are based on my feelings wheel)
this color code helps me see which things are bringing me joy and which are causing unnecessary stress or need some attention
i usually do some sort of spikey gesture on things that are causing either emotional or physical pain
for context, I am a person who walks through the world with light skinned privilege/advantage
if you don’t have an active practice around this, I recommend Resmaa Menakem’s “foundations in somatic abolitionism”.
i’ve heard folks describe this sensation as similar to someone calling you by the wrong name, mispronouncing your name, getting squirted with a squirt bottle…
strongly recommend this exercise to build empathy for how it feels to be referred to with language that affirms/does not affirm your identity
this is my interpretation of how my family is feeling– but this could also be done together as a family or group of people
when i would get flooded with purple, i could focus on breathing the purple out and filling my lungs with yellow/gold to replace it
this exercise has helped me notice that there’s not much red (anger) in my drawings– but then I do a body map to see where I’m holding tension or bracing… and find the red…
this can also be a great mental exercise to do when you get dressed in the morning or are trying on new clothes
do these clothes make me feel constricted/like I’m wearing them for someone else’s comfort
do these clothes make me feel like myself/like I’m wearing them for my own comfort and self expression
oof this one– i am forever working on turning these obligatory “yeses” into kind, protective, embodied “no’s” or “not right nows”
